WRITING.TITLE: My son asked me, "Dad, what's an alcoholic?"
WRITING.TEXT:
So I said, "Do you see those four trees? Well, an alcoholic would see eight."
He replied, "But Dad, I only see two."
Fun fact Ron Swanson has one brother, he told me so.

I had a group of 5 super close friends (4 guys, 1 girl), who I would see at least 3 times a week (as we all live nearby) and we would always holiday together. After 6 years guy 1 dated the girl and I'm not even joking, I saw them 4 times in the two years that they dated.
They broke up and the girl stopped talking to us all. So then I was down to 4.
Then Guy 2 started dating someone, not seen him in literally a year. Guy 3 started dating an Australia, after 6 months her visa ran out so he quit his fantastic job and moved to Australia to be with her. i have not seen him since. Guy 4 hasn't dated in this time so I see him a lot. Guy 1 bought a house with a girl he'd been seeing for 6 months (met the same week guy 2 met the australian), and I have seen him exactly twice since then, one was his birthday and the second time his girlfriend was abroad.
I get you fall in love but whenever I'm in a relationship I always make sure to still hang out with my friends.
Since whatsapp was invented I feel that people consider that being in touch and forget they haven't actually seen you for a while.

President of the Vatican city.
* Population of 800 or so people. * Pope exists so he can do all the meet and greets/travelling to see world leaders. * Can't mess up the economy as you're always guaranteed tourists. * Decent weather + can visit Rome whenever you like. * Get to see all the secret religious archives that they have hidden away.

Some Middle Eastern countries kill their stray dogs, this would include puppies. Though the term destroyed rather than murdered is used. Which I think actually sounds worst.
I know that in Mauritius they'd kill not only stray dogs but also owned dogs (with collars) that were wandering the streets, all so you can have an idyllic holiday. The news here ran a story about it and showed pictures of dead puppies, which I thought was a bit much to show on the news.

Question: How is the monarchy currently seen in Spain. They seem quiet distant from the people and , dare I say it, do not have the traditional Spanish look .
Older Spaniards liked the old King (Juan Carlos) because Franco groomed him to be Spains next dictator, once he died, but when he did die JC declared that Spain will be becoming a democracy. So for that the people were eternally grateful. It was due to this that people looked the other way for his very public mistresses and general law bending ways. Once the older generation started dying off and the younger liberals had more power the people turned against him and so he quickly rushed his son in to become King.
Our current King, Felipe (VI), is basically just there and avoiding all the scandals that have turned the people against most of his relatives. He married a 'commoner' but people weren't particularly bothered about that as they are with Kate.
So at the moment most people don't care about the King, as long as he doesn't get into any major scandals. Then I'm sure the monarchy would be over.

I'm bilingual, Spanish family but I was born and raised in London. I'm fluent in both and actually studied Spanish all the way to degree level. What I noticed is that people like me (bilingual from birth) can switch in and out of both languages very easily, especially in the same sentence.
People on my course who learnt Spanish as teenagers, no matter how much they studied over the years, never learnt that ability.
Even now when I talk to my uni buddies, when they switch languages there's always this pause before they do so, almost like they're pulling a lever in their head to switch languages.
